title: Noun Project Icon Design
text:
Noun Project is ‚Äúbuilding a global visual language that unites us‚Äù and provides icons for everything. I have a bunch of my own icon designs and my own bespoke icon collections on Noun Project that you can choose from to spice up your own projects. I add new designs often, so check back to see what‚Äôs available.
Checkout all of my icon designs over at my Noun Project profile page.
Noun Project supports creators when people download their icons. Whether you choose to buy one of my designs individually (fully customizable), sign up to their NounPro subscription service (full-access, in-app integration, and more), or just do a free basic download of my designs in black (with attribution), you directly support my work and allow me to continue creating great icons. I appreciate it immensely and hope you enjoy my designs.
For more information about how Noun Project works, checkout their About page.


Image Credit
happy octopus by Zach Bogart from the Noun Project

title: Koji Typeface
text:
Try Out Koji  Exploration and Drafting Notes
I‚Äôve been sketching out font ideas in the margins of college notebooks for years, so I thought it might be time to formalize one of them. The result is Koji, a typeface based off of a simple jig I would draw in my workbooks during class.
The main idea of Koji was to base all of the characters off of a simple template. But, as I began formally defining the font, it of course came down to some aesthetic choices. Creating this font was an incredible experience and I hope to improve it more and more, adding new characters to support more languages and tightening up each letter to improve usability.

title: Koji Typeface
text:
Included Unicode Blocks

Basic Latin (U+0020-U+007E)
Latin-1 Supplement (U+00A0-U+00FF)

title: Koji Typeface
text:
Why Koji?
Naming a font is arguably as hard as creating one. I could say it was chosen because Koji fungal blooms are sort of round like this font. Or I could say it‚Äôs a principal ingredient in fermenting soy sauce, a condiment that is simple yet complex, just like this font. But the truth is far less poetic: it came from an online word finder. I wanted a name that used an uppercase ‚ÄúK‚Äù and a lowercase ‚Äúj‚Äù because those are two of my favorite letters in this typeface. So I searched for a word that fit the bill and came across ‚ÄúKoji‚Äù and it just grew on me. It‚Äôs easy to say, it has a cool but as you now know somewhat tacked-on backstory, and it looks good when written in the font, which is always a plus. Overall, a simple and catchy name for what I hope is your new favorite font.

title: Koji Typeface
text:
Try it out!
If you try out the Koji typeface, consider throwing a digital coffee my way. Much appreciated.
Hope you enjoy the Koji typeface.

title: Bookworm
text:
It‚Äôs embedded below, though it‚Äôs easier to view on Observable.


If you enjoy this, feel free to fork it and track your own reading habits (or whatever else). And if you think this little project deserves a coffee, I‚Äôd welcome the gesture. It‚Äôs most likely going towards a hot cocoa or a tea, but it‚Äôll certainly be paired with whatever happens to be my current readie. Much appreciated. ‚òï
Happy reading‚Ä¶

title: (I knew it when I saw it)
I‚Äôll know it when I see it
text:
I tried making some collegiate notebook marginalia into a typeface, and it actually worked and you can try it. It‚Äôs called Koji, a highly geometric typeface I made by hand. Crazy respect for the crazy people who devote themselves to this. Also, I hate kerning sooo much.
I started  making icons for Noun Project after wanting some icon headers for a project I worked on over the summer in grad school. Turned into a fun hobby.





 Darn! That‚Äôs the end!

title: Using Callouts
text:
Look, a coding website!
I got this website up and running! Looking forward to being able to work on honing my skills and making is easy to post progress on that fact.
